ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a better understanding of Latin syntax and grammar.  I also improved my translation skills.

I learned a good amount of Sallust and Pliny, and leanred a lot about both grammar and vocabulary. I learned how to parse Latin words and their dictionary definitions, principal parts, and their function in the sentence.
reading authentic Latin prose (from Pliny and Sallust), review of grammar and vocabulary, developing sight reading skills
I developed knowledge on basic Latin grammatical constructions and how to translate and understand undoctored Latin prose.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: No weaknesses!  The course is run really well in a way that supports student engagement and learning.

Strengths: quizzes and tests balance out, participation is largely graded by effort rather than correctness. Sydnie is a great teacher, and makes time for you in office hours and questions in class.
It is sometimes difficult to get through so much material in a 50 minute class. 
I decided to take L3 after high school Latin, and the learning curve for me was very steep. If you are a first year and have decided to start out with this course right away, I would recommend that you are very confident in your knowledge of Latin grammar. If not, the only other option to study for quizzes is rote memorization, which is very time consuming.

Strengths: Instructor Sydnie Chavez was deeply invested in student's learning and was great at teaching students how to approach difficult passages in the readings.

Weaknesses: none
I enjoyed the pace and material covered in the curriculum.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!  It is a great class for anyone interested in upper level Latin translation.  It is the culmination of a lot of skills learned in earlier classes and is very rewarding.
Yes, absolutely. Its a great intermediate course for people that have previous knowledge of Latin but not enough to be able to read texts fluently.
Absolutely, the teaching of the course is great and the works of Sallust and Pliny are very interesting.
I would recommend this course to a student that has a solid background in Latin but is still hoping to improve their introductory skills.
